title: About me
text:
My name is Leonhard Reiter, but most people just call me Lenni1. I am a Master Student in (Economic) Psychology at the university of Vienna and a student assistant in Robert B√∂hm‚Äôs Team. There I help with conducting research, such as creating surveys and analysing data. I did an internship at Susann Fiedler‚Äôs group at the WU Vienna where I prepared a Bachelor course on Publication Bias detection methods such as p/z-curves regarding management research.
I am interested in how people engage, rate and interact with new technologies, ranging from vaccination to AI tool. Furthermore I am also interested in more meta-sciency topics such as p-mining, publication bias and how to help to improve science.
My work is strongly quantitative and I love doing and reading about statistics. Check my Github to see what I am currently working through. I am especially interested in Meta-Analysis Sometime I also dabble into Bayesian barbarism, participating in the 2024 edition of Richard McElreath‚Äôs ‚ÄúStatistical Rethinking‚Äù-Course. More broadly I am also interested in Machine Learning and text as data. I strongly advocate open-science and especially reproducible workflows. Check out my OSF to see more.
Beside science I like to cook, play Bass and take long walks in the Augarten.
If you would like to talk about statistics, science in general or to collaborate on a project, feel free to reach out to me via mail.

title: Off to the Sunset with Funnel Plots?
text:
# The Packages we need
library(tidyverse)    # Of course
library(metafor)      # Meta-Analysis stuff
library(metaviz)      # `viz_sunset`
Interpreting the results of a meta-analysis means interpreting graphs. One of the most famous and useful plots is the forest plot, which shows the individual and summary effects.
Another widely used visualization tool is the funnel plot. In its core basically just a scatter plot, funnel plots
Mainly used to check the model for signs of publication bias, it plots the observed effect sizes against a measure of precision
However, interpreting a standard funnel plot can be challenging. It is often difficult to differentiate between symptoms of publication bias and small-studies effects.
The goal of this blog post is to sway you away from standard funnel plots to embracing the sunset funnel plot.

title: Off to the Sunset with Funnel Plots?
text:
Power enhanced funnel plots
Making a sunset funnel plot is easy and straight forward. The metaviz package by Kossmeier et al. (2020) provides a straight forward function for it: viz_sunset().
When using metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010) to fit a model, you can then just feed it to viz_sunset().

d <- 
mozart |> 
  escalc(measure = "SMD",
         yi = d,
         sei = se,
         data = _)

res <- rma(yi, vi, data = d)
res


Random-Effects Model (k = 38; tau^2 estimator: REML)

tau^2 (estimated amount of total heterogeneity): 0.1464 (SE = 0.0532)
tau (square root of estimated tau^2 value):      0.3826
I^2 (total heterogeneity / total variability):   69.36%
H^2 (total variability / sampling variability):  3.26

Test for Heterogeneity:
Q(df = 37) = 108.2824, p-val < .0001

Model Results:

estimate      se    zval    pval   ci.lb   ci.ub      
  0.3751  0.0792  4.7367  <.0001  0.2199  0.5303  *** 

---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

viz_sunset(res,
           sig_contours = F,
           contours = T)







viz_funnel(res)

title: Off to the Sunset with Funnel Plots?
text:
The statistics
Beside values for the mean power viz_funnel also provides two estimates:

A test of excessive significance (Ioannidis & Trikalinos, 2007)
The R-Index


Test of excessive significance
First proposed by Ioannidis & Trikalinos (2007), the test for an excess of significant findings aims to do precisely that, to tell one, if the number of significant results
\[
z_i = \frac{y_i - \mbox{H}_0}{\sqrt{v_i}}
\]


R-Index

title: Publications
text:
Work in progress

I am currently working on a meta-analysis on a topic related to vaccination intention. My first article as first author is also currently under review. The topic is broadly use cases of generative AI in education.

title: Off to the Sunset with Funnel Plots?
text:
Creating a Sunset Funnel Plot
Making a sunset funnel plot is easy and straight forward. The metaviz package by Kossmeier et al. (2020) provides a straight forward function for it: viz_sunset().
When using metafor (Viechtbauer, 2010) to fit a model, you can then just feed it to viz_sunset().

title: Off to the Sunset with Funnel Plots?
text:
Further otuputs
viz_sunset() also provides multiple estimates for the power.
Beside values for the mean power viz_funnel further provides two estimates:

A test of excessive significance (Ioannidis & Trikalinos, 2007)
The R-Index


Test of excessive significance
First proposed by Ioannidis & Trikalinos (2007), the test for an excess of significant findings aims to do precisely that, to tell one, if the number of significant results
\[
z_i = \frac{y_i - \mbox{H}_0}{\sqrt{v_i}}
\]


R-Index
